title: Ansible - IaC using SSH
description: Tutorial about using Ansible to setup your VPS server using Ubuntu
author: Simon Scholz

children.value:
Ansible is a IaC (infrastructure as code) tool, which can automate a lot of tasks and makes setups reproducible.
Ansible has a concept of playbooks to be run to apply certain workflows, e.g., setting up a server using a VPS provider.
It is good practice to use a distributed version control system, e.g., GIT, to store all ansible files.
There are several ways to install ansible, which can be found here:
For Ubuntu it can be done like this:

props.className: language-bash shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai
props.code:
# Install pipx (if not already installed)
sudo apt install pipx

# Install Ansible
pipx install --include-deps ansible

props.className: language-bash shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai

In case port 22 is already occupied or you face other network issues you can configure the network of your VM.
And then you can change the port to talk to by using port forwarding:
For better security and convenience it is highly recommended to use ssh keys to connect to a machine via ssh.

props.className: language-bash shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai
props.code: ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "ansible"

Copy ssh key to the server
Now the generated ssh key has to be propagated to the server.

props.className: language-bash shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai

Let's create our first Ansible playbook called

- name: My first playbook

  become: true
  tasks:
    - name: Update repository index
      ansible.builtin.apt:
        update_cache: true
      when: ansible_distribution == "Ubuntu"

children.value: It is considered good practice to have a dedicated user to run the ansible playbooks.

Since that new user should also be a sudoer (allowed to run sudo commands),
we'll add a

props.code: echo "simon-ansible ALL=(ALL) NOPASSWD: ALL" >> files/sudoer_simon_ansible

props.className: language-yml shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai
props.code:
---
- name: My first playbook
  hosts: all
  become: true
  tasks:
    - name: Update repository index
      ansible.builtin.apt:
        update_cache: true
      changed_when: false
      when: ansible_distribution == "Ubuntu"

    - name: Add README.md
      ansible.builtin.copy:
        src: README.md
        dest: /home/simon
        owner: root
        group: root
        mode: "0644"

    - name: Add simon-ansible user
      ansible.builtin.user:
        name: simon-ansible
        groups:
          - root

    - name: Add ssh key (user simon-ansible)
      authorized_key:
        user: simon-ansible
        key: "ssh-ed25519 AAAAC3NzaC1lZDI1NTE5AAAAIM0IWm4fVLFOYFydagOnkqaEvu9jnTUARRUYfQ0XnxFR ansible"

    - name: Add sudoers file (user simon-ansible)
      ansible.builtin.copy:
        src: sudoer_simon_ansible
        dest: /etc/sudoers.d/simon-ansible
        owner: root
        group: root
        mode: "0644"

Having all tasks inside one playbook will decrease the readability
and harder to maintain.
Roles can be used to organize certain tasks in a dedicated file structure,
which make them reusable and fosters proper separation of concerns.
Basically our current playbook does 3 things right now:
creates and configures a dedicated ansible user
We now intend to move these tasks into respective roles and just let the playbook delegate to these roles:
Therefore we create the following directories and files:

props.className: language-bash shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai
props.code:
mkdir -p roles/apt_update/tasks/ \
         roles/copy_readme/tasks/ \
         roles/copy_readme/files/ \
         roles/user_create/tasks/ \
         roles/user_create/files/ \
&& touch roles/apt_update/tasks/main.yml \
         roles/copy_readme/tasks/main.yml \
         roles/user_create/tasks/main.yml \
&& mv files/README.md roles/copy_readme/files/README.md \
&& mv files/sudoer_simon_ansible roles/user_create/files/sudoer_simon_ansible \
&& rm -r files

But we now have cleaned up a bit and have clear separation of concerns.
Note that the roles are also mentioned in the console output.
If you want to create a new role from scratch the
cli can be used for this:

children.value: you can browse several collections and roles provided by the community.

So if you intend to do some basic operations using Ansible chances are that other's already did that before you.
So instead of reinventing the wheel, you probably might want to search for a collection or role, which suits your needs.
At least you can get inspirations from existing roles, that do archive a similar outcome you'd want to have.
You can even provide your own roles starting with the
You can install certain roles using the

props.className: language-bash shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai
props.code:
ansible-galaxy role install namespace.role_name

# e.g.
ansible-galaxy role install geerlingguy.security

children.value: Doing so will usually result in the role ending up in the
param the path can be changed:

props.className: language-bash shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai
props.code: ansible-galaxy role install --roles-path . geerlingguy.security

children.value: file to specify, which roles should be installed.
file you have plenty of options:

- The source of the role. Use the format namespace.role_name, if downloading from Galaxy; otherwise, provide a URL pointing to a repository within a Git based SCM. See the examples below. This is a required attribute.
-     Specify the SCM. As of this writing only git or hg are allowed. See the examples below. Defaults to git.
-     The version of the role to download. Provide a release tag value, commit hash, or branch name. Defaults to the branch set as a default in the repository, otherwise defaults to the master.
-     Download the role to a specific name. Defaults to the Galaxy name when downloading from Galaxy, otherwise it defaults to the name of the repository.
An example could look like this:

props.className: language-yml shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai
props.code:
- src: geerlingguy.security
  version: 2.4.0
- src: geerlingguy.docker
  version: 7.4.1

children.value: It is recommended to specify the version to avoid unexpected problems with newer versions of a role.
To install the roles from the
file the following command can be run:

props.className: language-bash shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai
props.code: ansible-galaxy install -r requirements.yml

children.value:
Blindly trusting third party dependencies is never a good idea and especially when it comes to ssh on your servers.
So please be sure to review the roles or collections from the Ansible Galaxy or anywhere else before using them.
